citeinfo.title: Total Polychlorinated Biphenyl (PCB) Concentrations in Fish from the Davis Pond Freshwater Postdiversion Sampling (2007-2009) with a Comparison to Prediversion Levels (2001)

pubinfo.publish: U.S. Geological Survey, National Wetlands Research Center

descript.abstract:
The diversion of freshwater from the Mississippi River is intended to mitigate saltwater intrusion from the Gulf of Mexico and to lessen the concomitant loss of wetland areas. Though effective, freshwater diversion can affect wildlife and habitat; therefore, prediversion and postdiversion data collections are necessary to identify effects. The Davis Pond freshwater diversion area is located between the Mississippi River and Bayou Lafourche and extends to Barataria Bay Basin, Louisiana. Results and interpretations from the prediversion biomonitoring done in 2001- which included data on fish, eagles, and bivalves - are presented in the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, "Davis Pond Freshwater Prediversion Biomonitoring Study: Freshwater Fisheries and Eagles." The postdiversion data generated approximately 6 years later from the sampling of fish whole bodies are presented here in this USGS Data Series. An accompanying log of postdiversion study site photographs was also produced in USGS Data Series 605, "Photographic Images Captured While Sampling for Bald Eagles near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure in Barataria Bay, Louisiana (2009-10).
Figures 5A and 5C represent the concentration of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) detected in largemouth bass, blue catfish and striped mullet samples collected in 2007-2009, approximately six years after the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure was operational. Figure 5B compares these concentrations to those collected in the 2001 prediversion study. Samples are from the Mississippi River, Lake Cataouatche, Bayou Couba, and Lake Salvador.
descript.purpose: The purpose of performing both prediversion and postdiversion monitoring was to obtain contaminants data to evaluate potential impacts of the operations of the Davis Pond freshwater diversion structure on fish, bivalves, and eagles in the downstream marsh area.

spdom.descgeog: Southeastern Louisiana near the Davis Pond Freshwater Diversion Structure. Collection sites in: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River.

taxonsys.taxonpro: Species were collected and identified by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries personnel who have pre-existing knowledge of fish identification.
taxonsys.taxoncom: All fish collected were identified to species.

attracc.attraccr: Standard quality-control and quality-assurance checks were performed by using duplicate samples, spiked samples, standard reference materials, and procedural blanks, and the limits of detection were defined as the Student's t for 99 percent confidence times the standard deviation of seven replicate measurements of the same low-level sample (Code of Federal Regulations, 2006).

dataqual.complete:
This study is a follow-up to measurements of contaminants in the Davis Pond area prediversion, in 2001. The prediversion study examined fish, bivalves, and eagles. This postdiversion study only contains the results from fish sampling.
Figure 5 is complete and contains data where concentrations were detected. PCB concentrations were below detectable levels for the majority of prediversion fish specimens tested (28 out of 36 samples). Minimum detection levels for PCBs were not declared in the 2008 or 2011 studies.

method.methdesc:
To collect data for the contaminants testing at Davis Pond in both the prediversion (2001) and postdiversion (2007-2009) studies, fish were collected according to a final plan dated October 31, 1995 (U.S. Army Engineer District, 1995). Fish were collected by Louisiana Department of Wildlife and Fisheries (LDWF) personnel from four sites: Lake Salvador, Bayou Couba, Lake Cataouatche, and the Mississippi River, using electroshock and gill and hoop nets. Thirty-six fish were harvested, 12 fish from each of three species, with 3 individuals per species per site. Species included largemouth bass, blue catfish, and striped mullet.
Sample collections were performed in accordance with protocols of the USGS Biomonitoring of Environmental Status and Trends (BEST) Program (Schmitt and others, 1995; Schmitt, Blazer, and others, 1999; Smith and others 2002) and the National Water-Quality Assessment Program (Crawford and Luoma, 1993).

citeinfo.title: Guidelines for Studies of Contaminants in Biological Tissues for the National Water-Quality Assessment Program

method.methdesc:
Prediversion: After fish were collected for sampling, fish whole bodies were frozen at -20 degrees Celsius until analysis.
Postdiversion: Samples were stored in precleaned jars and frozen (-20 degrees Celsius) until analysis. Automated extraction apparatus (ASE 200 Accelerated Solvent Extractor, Dionex, Sunnyvale, Calif.) was used with 0.5-15 g of tissue samples having been mixed with Hydromatrix (Agilent Technologies, Santa Clara, Calif.). Using 100 percent dichloromethane inside stainless steel extraction cells at 100 degrees Celsius and 200 pounds per square inch (psi), the extracts were dissolved and were collected in 60-milliliter (mL) glass vials and concentrated to 1-3 mL by using an evaporative solvent reduction apparatus (water bath or TurboVap II Evaporation System, Caliper Life Sciences, Hopkinton, Mass.). Sample aliquots were weighed for determining percentage of lipids, and the remaining portions were processed through a clean-up column (activated silica gel and alumina) and high-performance liquid chromatography to minimize matrix interference. Extracts concentrated to a final volume of 0.5 mL were submitted for determination of aliphatic, aromatic, and chlorinated hydrocarbons.

citeinfo.title: Method 3545--Pressurized Fluid Extraction (PFE)

citeinfo.title: Optimization and Comparison of MAE, ASE and SIXHLET Extraction for the Determination of HCH Isomers in Soil Samples

method.methdesc:
Prediversion: To test for organic contaminants in 2001, separation of OC pesticides and PCBs was done on a silicic acid chromatographic column following analysis by megabore column electron capture gas chromatography (Mississippi State Chemical Laboratory [MSCL] standard operating procedure [SOP] 1.267). Total PCBs were calculated by adding the sum of Aroclors 1242, 1248, 1254, and 1260.
Postdiversion: Quantitation was performed on an HP model 5890 gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with electron capture detection (ECD). Between 1 and 5 mL of sample was injected by using an HP model 7673A autosampler. The primary capillary column was a J&W DB-5 (30-m x 24-mm ID and 0.25-mm film thickness). The second column, a confirmation column, was a J&W DB-17HT (30-m x 0.25-mm ID and 0.15-mm film thickness). The inlet system was splitless, and the carrier gas was helium at a flow rate of 1 mL/min. For the analysis of standard halogenated hydrocarbons, the temperature of the injection port was 275 degrees Celsius, and the detector was 325 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 100 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min. The ramp rate was 5 degrees Celsius/min to 140 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min, followed by a ramp rate of 1.5 degrees Celsius/min to 250 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 1 min and a ramp rate of 10 degrees Celsius/min to 300 degrees Celsius with a final hold time of 5 min.
Additional column chromatography is required to separate polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) from toxaphene/pesticides and planar PCBs. An aliquot of the extract prior to clean-up with high-performance liquid chromatography was processed through a 3 percent deactivated silica gel column packed in dichloromethane, which was then flushed with pentane. The sample extract was transferred to the top of the column and flushed with 100 mL of pentane; this fraction contained PCBs and dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethanes (DDTs). This fraction was further processed by column chromatography packed with activated carbon/Celite (1:19 and 5 percent by weight) (World Minerals Inc., Santa Barbara, Calif.) and flushing with 1:4 dichloromethane/cyclohexane mixture. The instrument was operated in the splitless mode with helium as the carrier gas with a flow rate of 1 mL/min. The temperature of the injection port was 275 degrees Celsius, and the detector was 325 degrees Celsius. The initial oven temperature was 100 degrees Celsius, held for 1 min. The ramp rate was 10 degrees Celsius/min to 150 degrees Celsius, followed by a ramp rate of 6.0 degrees Celsius/min to 270 degrees Celsius with a hold time of 3 min.
The retention time of sample analytes fell within 15 seconds of the retention time of analytes in a calibration standard or retention index solutions. The levels of aroclor and toxaphene were determined by using retention index solutions of both complex mixtures. Aroclor were determined in a similar method to that described by the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.

procstep.procdesc: Postdiversion detected polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) contamination levels were collected and entered into a spreadsheet.
Polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) concentrations (in parts per million wet weight) from the prediversion and postdiversion studies were graphed for comparison.

enttyp.enttypd: A spreadsheet of polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) levels in micrograms per gram (wet weight) from fish collected for the Davis Pond postdiversion sampling.

attrdomv.udom: Number assigned to collected fish specimen
Number assigned to collected fish specimen

overview.eaover: 5A - Total polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) (wet weight; micrograms per gram) from largemouth bass (LMB; Micropterus salmoides), blue catfish (CAT; Ictalurus furcatus), and striped mullet (MUL; Mugil cephalus) collected from Davis Pond postdiversion sites from December 2007 through February 2009. For total PCB concentration data, see Figure 5C (Jenkins and others, 2011).
overview.eadetcit: Jenkins, J.A., Olivier, H.M., Draugelis-Dale, R.O., and Kaller, M.D., 2011, Davis Pond freshwater diversion biomonitoring - prediversion and postdiversion freshwater fish data: U.S. Geological Survey Data Series 604, 5 p.

overview.eaover: 5B - Three-dimensional comparison of Davis Pond prediversion and postdiversion total polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) concentrations by wet weight (in micrograms per gram). For prediversion total PCB data see Table 3 (Jenkins and others, 2008). For postdiversion concentrations see Figure 5C (Jenkins and others, 2011).
overview.eadetcit: Jenkins, J.A., Olivier, H.M., Draugelis-Dale, R.O., and Kaller, M.D., 2011, Davis Pond freshwater diversion biomonitoring - prediversion and postdiversion freshwater fish data: U.S. Geological Survey Data Series 604, 5 p.

Jenkins, J.A., Bourgeois, E.B., and Jeske, C.W., 2008, Davis Pond freshwater prediversion biomonitoring study - freshwater fisheries and eagles: U.S. Geological Survey Scientific Investigations Report 2008-5067, 102 p.

overview.eaover: 5C - Polychlorinated biphenyl (PCB) wet weight (in micrograms per gram; parts per million) concentrations from fish collected from sites in southeastern Louisiana during the Davis Pond postdiversion study, December 2007 through February 2009. [LMB, largemouth bass; CAT, blue catfish; MUL, striped mullet. RIVER, Mississippi River; CATA, Lake Cataouatche site; COUBA, Bayou Couba site; CAMP, Lake Salvador site].
